facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1953 arises from High Court of Allahabad judgment dated 1st October 1953 in Civil Miscellaneous Writ No. 379 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1953. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 1st October, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscellaneous Writ No. 379 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Article 226 to Allahabad High Court praying for writ quashing President's order dated 17th April 1953 ordering compulsory retirement after 25 years service.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of an application made by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad under, article 226 of the Constitution praying for an appropriate writ quashing the order made by the President of India on the 17th April, 1953, ordering the companypulsory retirement of the appellant who had companypleted 25 years qualifying service.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ application on 1st October 1953 but granted certificate under Article 132 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated the 1st October, 1953, dismissed the application but, as the case involved a substantial question of the interpretation of the Constitution, the High Court granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant passed Civil Engineering degree from Thomason College, Roorkee in 1922, stood first, awarded Gold Medal.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts may be shortly stated as follows The appellant passed his Civil Engineering degree examinaion from the Thomason College. Roorkee, in 1922. He stood first in order of merit and carried away the Gold Medal and other prizes awarded to the best student of that year.

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Assistant Executive Engineer in Indian Service of Engineers by Secretary of State for India with effect from 20th October 1923.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed by the Secretary of State for India in Council to the Indian Service of Engineers as an Assistant Executive Engineer with effect from the 20th October, 1923. The companyditions governing the appellants terms of appointment, promotion, leave, pension, etc.,

facts.text: Terms of appointment recorded in letter from India Office, London dated 13th February 1924.

anchor.surface_text: will be found recorded in a letter issued from India Office, London, on the 13th February, 1924. A companyy of that letter is annexed to the Petition filed under article 226.

facts.text: Appellant promoted to officiating Superintending Engineer in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 the appellant was promoted to the rank of officiating Superintending Engineer.

facts.text: Fresh agreement entered between appellant, Governor of United Provinces and Governor General of India on 16th September 1948 confirming 1924 terms.

anchor.surface_text: After the attainment of independence by India a fresh agreement was entered into by and between the appellant the Governor of the United Provinces and the Governor General of India on the 16th September, 1948 companyfirming the appellants terms of appointment companytained in the letter of the 13th February, 1924.

facts.text: Appellant recommended for confirmation as Superintending Engineer but not confirmed, continued officiating.

anchor.surface_text: At or about this time the appellant along with several other officers was recommended by the Chief Engineer for companyfirmation as Superintending Engineer. The appellant, however, was number companyfirmed but companytinued to officiate as Superintending Engineer until the time hereinafter stated.

facts.text: On 4th January 1950, PWD UP Govt sent letter to Chief Engineer Irrigation requesting to ask appellant to show cause within 3 weeks why compulsorily retired under Art 465-A CSR.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th January, 1950, the Public Works Department of the U.P. Government addressed a letter to the Chief Engineer, Irrigation Branch U.P. requesting him to companymunicate the letter enclosed therewith to the appellant and to ask him to submit as early as possible whatever explanation he might desire to give.

facts.text: Show cause letter alleged: 1. systematic gross overpayments to benefit contractors; 2. spent public money for personal convenience; 3. devious unscrupulous methods; six instances listed.

anchor.surface_text: The enclosed letter called upon the appellant to show cause within three weeks why he should number-be companypulsorily retired under the provisions of article 465-A, Civil Service Regulations,as it appeared  1  that he had been making systematic and gross overpayments apparently for numberother reason than to benefit the companytractors companycerned and  2  that he had spent large amounts of public money for his own personal companyvenience and  3  that he had taken recourse to devious and unscrupulous methods.

facts.text: Appellant submitted explanations to show cause letter.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted his explanations which, together with the Chief Engineers companyments thereon, were placed before the Union Public Service Commission.

facts.text: Union Public Service Commission concluded five out of six charges proved.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission came to the companyclusion that five out of the six charges had been proved and submitted their report accordingly.

facts.text: President of India on 17th April 1953 ordered appellant to retire forthwith under Note 1 to Article 465-A CSR after considering case and UPSC recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th April, 1953, the President, after companysidering the case and the recommendations of the Commission, decided that the appellant should retire forthwith from service under Note I to article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition on 24th April 1953 before Allahabad High Court under Art 226 to quash President's order as illegal without opportunity to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: Before this order companyld be served on him the appellant on the 24th April, 1953, filed -before the Allahabad High Court a petition under article 226 of the Constitution praying that the order made by the President on the 17th April, 1953, be quashed

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal directed against High Court dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the High Court dismissed the application on, the 1st October, 1953. The present appeal is directed against that order of dismissal.

facts.text: Appellant is Shri Shyam Lal, I.S.E.

anchor.surface_text: Under the rules Government reserve the right to companypulsorily retire any officer whose retention in service they companysider number to be in the public interest. This is number, therefore, a formal enquiry under the Classification. Control and Appeal Rules but before taking the action indicated above Government were pleased to and an opportunity to Shri Shyam Lal, I.S.E.,

facts.text: Officers of Indian Service of Engineers included in officers mentioned in Article 349-A CSR.

anchor.surface_text: Officers of the Indian Service of Engineers are included amongst the officers mentioned in article 349-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

facts.text: Government of India Resolution No. 1085-E.A. dated 15th November 1919 announced new rules on retiring pensions applicable to Public Works Department officers joining after 29th August 1919.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that by Resolution No. 1085-E.A. passed on the 15th November, 1919, and published in the gazette of India on the same date the Government of India, Finanance Department with the approval of the Secretary of State for India, announced certain new rules relating to retiring pensions

facts.text: New rules from 1919 Resolution included absolute right to retire after 25 years service without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The material I part of rule 4 of these new rules was as follows - Government will have an absolute right to retire any officer after he has companypleted twenty-five years service, without necessity to give reasons and without any claim for companypensation in addition to pension,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Article 465-A and Note 1 applicable to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the High Court, though on different grounds, that the first question raised by the appellant must be answered against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court held compulsory retirement under Note 1 Art 465-A not amounting to dismissal or removal, not attracting Art 311.

anchor.surface_text: The foregoing discussion necessarily leads us. to the companyclusion that a companypulsory retirement does number amount to dismissal or removal and, therefore, does number attract the provisions of article 311 of the Constitution

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore., is that this appeal fails and must stand dismissed.

holdings.text: Article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations is applicable to and binding on the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the High Court, though on different grounds, that the first question raised by the appellant must be answered against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules announced in 1919 Resolution No. 1085-E.A. applied to appellant who joined in 1923, validated by s96B(4) GOI Act 1919, incorporated into CSR without creating new rules; 'retains' in Note 1 confirms pre-existing right.

holdings.text: Officers of the Indian Service of Engineers are included amongst the officers mentioned in article 349-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: Officers of the Indian Service of Engineers are included amongst the officers mentioned in article 349-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct statement confirming scope of Art 349-A as applicable to ISE officers.

holdings.text: Compulsory retirement under Note 1 to Article 465-A does not amount to dismissal or removal from service.

anchor.surface_text: The foregoing discussion necessarily leads us. to the conclusion that a compulsory retirement does not amount to dismissal or removal and,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lacks stigma/charge of misconduct; no loss of earned pension unlike dismissal/removal; not listed as penalty in CCA Rule 49; distinguished from terminations attracting Art 311 by precedents and rules.

holdings.text: Compulsory retirement under Note 1 to Article 465-A does not attract the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: therefore, does not attract the provisions of article 311 of the Constitution or of rule 55 and that, therefore, the order of the President cannot be challenged

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not dismissal/removal/reduction; Art 311 safeguards only apply to penalties involving opportunity; retirement based on service length and public interest, not personal fault.

holdings.text: Note 1 to Article 465-A is not repugnant to Article 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Both the questions under consideration must also be answered against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since compulsory retirement neither invokes Art 311 nor imposes penalty/removal, no repugnancy; absolute right retained from pre-Constitution rules.

holdings.text: The President's order of compulsory retirement is valid and the appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore., is that this appeal fails and must stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; Art 465-A applicable and Art 311 inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be mentioned here that although the power of dismissal at pleasure was subject to the provisions of this Act and of the rules made thereunder the Judicial Committee held in Rangachari v. Secretary of State 1  and in Venkatarao v. Secretary of State 2  that those opening words of section 96B 1  did number qualify the unfettered discretion of the Crown to dismiss a servant at pleasure

precedents.cited_proposition: opening words of section 96B(1) did not qualify the unfettered discretion of the Crown to dismiss a servant at pleasure and the remedy of the servant for the violation of the rules was not by a law suit but by an appeal of an official or political kind

Lals case 1  that removal was within section 240 3 , which companyclusion implies that removal is companyprised within dismissals The position, therefore, is that both under the rules and according to the last mentioned decision of the Judicial Committee there is numberdistinction between a dismissal and a removal except that the former disqualifies from future employment while the latter does number.

precedents.citation: Satischandra Anand v. The Union of India 1 [1953 S.C.R. 655]

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, in our recent decision L.R- 75 I,A. 225 A.I.R. 1948 P.C. 121. in Satischandra Anand v. The Union of India 1  it has been said that these terms have been used in the same sense in article 311. Removal, like dismissal, numberdoubt brings about a termination of service but every termination of service does number amount to dismissal or removal. A reference to the Explanation to rule 49 quoted above will show that several kinds of termination of service do number amount to removal or dismissal. Our recent decision in Satishchandra Anand v. The Union of India supra fully supports the conclusion that article 311 does number apply to all cases of termination of service.

precedents.case_name: Satishchandra Anand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal and removal have been used in the same sense in article 311 and article 311 does not apply to all cases of termination of service such as termination of temporary contract service
precedents.cited_holding: article 311 does not apply to termination of contract for temporary service

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore., is that this appeal fails and must stand dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; President's order of compulsory retirement upheld
